repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Initial implementation for sharing C utility functions. The main goal of this PR is to introduce plumbing needed for sharing C utility functions. This PR currently shares:

* `__Pyx_Py3MetaclassPrepare`
* `__Pyx_Py3ClassCreate`
* `__Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod0`
* `__Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod1`

In subsequent PRs additional functions can be added - see #6963. Additional functions can require more adjustments in utility code and also in Cython code.

comment_data.body:
Continuing discussion in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6963#discussion_r2161926443

I have implemented as proposed but now I am thinking. Currently, in any case we support exporting/offloading C utilities having only function prototypes in `.proto` section. Hence does it make sense to have another section? We can just mark utility as exported and parse `.proto` section:

```c
/////////////// Py3ClassCreate.proto ///////////////
//@shared
static PyObject *__Pyx_Py3MetaclassPrepare(PyObject *metaclass, PyObject *bases, PyObject *name, PyObject *qualname,
                                           PyObject *mkw, PyObject *modname, PyObject *doc); /*proto*/
static PyObject *__Pyx_Py3ClassCreate(PyObject *metaclass, PyObject *name, PyObject *bases, PyObject *dict,
                                      PyObject *mkw, int calculate_metaclass, int allow_py2_metaclass); /*proto*/
```
But in this case I need to ensure that comments are allowed in the parsing though...
Maybe since moved to global, we can improve name not sure what the new name should be though. Any idea is welcome.

comment_data.body:
Rather than injecting new code layout parts into the file at random points, they should always exist in the `code_layout` list and just stay empty if they are unused.

I think all of the `__Pyx_ExportFunction()` calls, ~including the already existing ones,~ can go into a separate C function called by the module init function (maybe `__Pyx_ExportUtilityFunctions`) with a separate code layout part. The new shared functions can then just add code to that part.

The same applies to the function importing. Just add a C function (and layout section) for that as well, leave it empty if unused, fill it with function imports (and maybe also the shared module import) if used. Inside of such a function, you're free to use your own local variables and don't need to resort to allocating temps etc.

EDIT: The existing function export code already uses a separate function, so those for the utility functions should go into a new one, see above.

comment_data.body:
Ah, seeing this combination now helped me understand that the variable names intend to distinguish the two cases of using or being the shared module, right? That was totally not clear to me before. Then I suggest:
```suggestion
        using_shared_utility_module = bool(self.module_node.scope.context.shared_utility_qualified_name)
        in_shared_utility_module = bool(self.module_node.scope.context.options.shared_c_file_path)
```

But please move this entire code section out of `Code.py`. It seems a better fit as separate methods in `ModuleNode` for the "in" and "using" case, called before `finalize_main_c_code()`, rather than being a part of this method here. It doesn't have to do anything with the finalisation, it's really something that is part of the module's functionality.

comment_data.body:
> Everything call related is usually intended to be inlined in one way or another. 

But this function is not marked as `inline` hence it is not 100% true. Yes, I am aware that modern C compilers are able to determine and inline the function based on code analysis but still we are not sure. I mean if this function should be inline it should not be marked as `inline`. And if it is not marked so it can be moved to shared modules...

> The two method call sections are not good candidates for moving out of the module.

Hmm so it means that `__Pyx_PyObject_CallMethod0` should not be used as shared?

Functions this small really shouldn't need to go through a function call, let alone a function pointer. The C compiler should just inline the C-API function call here.

import os
import re
import shutil
import tempfile
from glob import glob

comment_data.body:
It took me quite a while to understand this back and forth calling and the interaction between init function and export/import code generation. Especially the `set_call_code` method was totally opaque to me at first and needed some research to understand.

That makes me wonder if there isn't a better way to encapsulate this. What do you think of a class like this, to be passed around wherever it's needed:
```python
class SharedUtilityExporter:
    def __init__(self, shared_utility_functions, shared_c_file_path, shared_utility_qualified_name, init_module_code):
        ...
        self.has_shared_imports = ...
        self.has_shared_exports = ...
        subfunction = ...
        self.import_code = subfunction(...) if self.has_shared_imports else None
        self.export_code = subfunction(...) if self.has_shared_exports else None

    # to be called from the module init code:
    def call_import_code(self, code): ...
    def call_export_code(self, code): ...

    # to be called after generating the module:
    @contextmanager
    def generate_exports(self, code): ...
    @contextmanager
    def generate_imports(self, code): ...
```
This is just a rough sketch out of the top of my head, so don't consider the names or signatures carved in stone. But I think it would better separate the concerns here. (Basically, if two sides fight about who's responsible, maybe someone else should be.)

comment_data.body:
Why do we need both sections? I find it annoying enough to keep impl and proto in sync (because I always forget to change proto after coding up the right way to change the impl), but having a part of proto appear also in export seems even more annoying, because then we have three places to update.

export must be self-contained, so I'd just let the utility code write out export before proto, and leave proto out completely if it's really not needed (and would thus be empty).

Or do we have cases where export would really be different from the corresponding declarations in proto?
Is it intentional that one uses `context.options` and the other just `context`?

comment_data.body:
Hmm I am fine with that I just misunderstand your comment before. Hence, I propose following:

```c
/////////////// Py3ClassCreate.proto ///////////////
@shared_utility

static PyObject *__Pyx_Py3MetaclassPrepare(PyObject *metaclass, PyObject *bases, PyObject *name, PyObject *qualname,
```

When `@shared_utility` attribute is present the proto part will be parsed by the shared utility code and processed accordingly. Do you have comments/objections to that approach?

I can't tell for sure, but my gut feeling is that the interface exported by the shared utility code might not be the same as that of the internally included utility code. I might be wrong and it could turn out the be always identical, in which case a tag is just fine. But I'd expect parts of the utility code to be only used inside of the shared module by other utility code, which could still need the declarations before the code. Maybe even without actually exporting anything at all to the outside world.

>  my gut feeling is that the interface exported by the shared utility code might not be the same as that of the internally included utility code

Hmm for now I am aiming `.export` and `.proto` to be identical but in future it can be generalised.

 > export must be self-contained, so I'd just let the utility code write out export before proto, and leave proto out completely if it's really not needed (and would thus be empty).
 
Hence, now I don't understand honestly your approach. We need `.proto` block in case of shared utility is not loaded and we need `.export` block in case of shared utility loaded. 

**For now** both blocks must be the same because `.proto` block is not used when shared utility is loaded and in reverse when shared utility is not used. if `.proto` block would be different with `.export` we would be missing some C declarations, because I understand `.proto` block in a way that all declarations containted there are used in other utilities. 
 
 Edit: sorry for my poor english :-(

Ah, right  in Py3.8, `collections.abc.Iterable` doesn't support item type declarations yet.

I could also live with a type annotation as string or even a comment that names the type. If the goal is just to remember the type of the input, either seem perfectly ok.

EDIT: I now saw that you used `typing.Sequence`  that's fine, too.

+class SharedUtilityExporter:
+    """
+    Class responsible for generating code responsible for importing and exporting shared utility functions.
+
+    This class is designed mark positions where the functions are being called by `call_import_code()`/`call_export_code()`.
+    The function calls and import/export functions are generated when `generate_exporting_functions()`
+    is called. This approach is needed because the list of the shared functions is known in the later stages
+    of compilation.
+    """
+    def __init__(self, mod_init_subfunction, scope, pos):
+        self.in_shared_utility_module = bool(scope.context.shared_c_file_path)
+        self.using_shared_utility_module = bool(scope.context.shared_utility_qualified_name)

comment_data.body:
You're not calling this method at all if we have nothing to export, so we can safely assume here that we always have something to export. In any case, you cannot call the utility code without first including it, so the `use_utility_code()` cannot be conditional.
```suggestion
        code.globalstate.use_utility_code(
            UtilityCode.load_cached("GetApiDict", "ImportExport.c"))
        code.putln(
            f"{api_dict} = __Pyx_ApiExport_GetApiDict(); "
            f"{code.error_goto_if_null(api_dict, self.pos)}"
        )
```

The return code annotation is incorrect. If both conditional parts are true, the method will return a sequence, not a bool value.
```suggestion
    def has_shared_exports(self, shared_func_definitions: Sequence[Code.SharedFunctionDecl]):
        return self.in_shared_utility_module and shared_func_definitions

    def has_shared_imports(self, shared_func_definitions: Sequence[Code.SharedFunctionDecl]):
        return self.using_shared_utility_module and shared_func_definitions
```
(It's interesting that this wasn't found by CI. I thought we had a mypy checker running, but apparently not on our code base.)

comment_data.body: There is an unwritten convention that things like `code` and `env` tend to go last in the method attribute list. Or maybe `code` last and `env` early, I don't remember right now. It's debatable whether the new `shared_utility_exporter` belongs in the same category, but since it's much more common to see `code` and `env` being passed around, I suggest sticking to the convention and inserting the new argument earlier.

comment_data.body:
- Add our familiar `/*proto*/` marker at the end of the line.
- Use a local variable instead of repeatedly looking up the code writer.
```suggestion
    def _put_shared_function_declarations(self, global_state: "GlobalState") -> None:
        proto_block = global_state[self.proto_block]
        proto_block.putln(f'/* {self.name} */')
        for shared in self.shared_utility_functions:
            # Convert function declarations to static function pointers.
            proto_block.putln(f'static {shared.ret}(*{shared.name})({shared.params}); /*proto*/')
        proto_block.putln()
```
 which then suggests that you don't actually need to pass in the `global_state` here but can just pass in the code writer for the `proto_block` as `code` argument. It's always good if we can minimize our dependencies on the outside world.

comment_data.body:
I personally prefer only to share functions that are explicitly declared via `.export` block. If any dependency is needed also by other utility or it is needed by Cython logic it should be automatically loaded and included in any case.

EDIT: automatic sharing of dependencies can be tricky too because not **all** utility functions can be easily shared... If dependency contains macros and other funny stuff in the `.proto` block there is not simple way how to share it..

+            # Convert function declarations to static function pointers.

+        global_state[self.proto_block].putln()

+        has_shared_utility_code = bool(
+            self.shared_utility_functions and output.module_node.scope.context.shared_utility_qualified_name
+        )
+
+        if self.requires and not has_shared_utility_code:
             for dependency in self.requires:
                 output.use_utility_code(dependency)

@@ -107,6 +108,108 @@ def generate_c_code_config(env, options):
     ('__ge__', '__lt__'): (True, '', None),
 }
 
+class SharedUtilityExporter:
+    """
+    Class responsible for generating code that imports and exports shared utility functions.
+
+    Mark the positions where the functions should be called with `call_import_code()`/`call_export_code()`.
+    The function calls and import/export functions are generated when `generate_exporting_functions()`
+    is called. This approach is needed because the list of the shared functions is only known in the later
+    stages of compilation.
+    """
+    def __init__(self, pos, mod_init_subfunction, scope):
+        self.in_shared_utility_module = bool(scope.context.shared_c_file_path)
+        self.using_shared_utility_module = bool(scope.context.shared_utility_qualified_name)
+        self.pos = pos
+        self.scope = scope
+        self.import_code = mod_init_subfunction("Shared function import code")
+        self.export_code = mod_init_subfunction("Shared function export code")
+
+    def has_shared_exports(self, shared_func_definitions: Sequence[Code.SharedFunctionDecl]):
+        return self.in_shared_utility_module and shared_func_definitions
+
+    def has_shared_imports(self, shared_func_definitions: Sequence[Code.SharedFunctionDecl]):
+        return self.using_shared_utility_module and shared_func_definitions

comment_data.body: If dependencies have nothing to export, then they become internal utility code of the shared module. That seems fine to me. The shared module is just a Cython module. If the proto block doesn't pose problems in other modules, why should it be problematic in the shared module?

commit.message: Initial implementation of shared C utility code
Multiple functons can be shared now
Add new shared functions + fix import issue
Use ObjectHandling shared utility code + adjust unittests
Avoid Compilation warning when cimport function is not needed
Parse exported function proto instead of composing it from parameter
